The authors of the Constitution did not want to hinder the President's ability to defend the country, but they wanted to protect against abuses by giving Congress an important role. The War Powers Resolution in 1973 was an attempt to expand on the original intent of the framers, and clarify the respective roles of Congress and the Presidency.

While I fully expect the anti-war folks to lose the case, legally I feel it is at least legitimate. The flaws in stormin norman's arguments are as follows:
 
 His constitutional analysis is unpersuasive. First of all, the president's power as commander in chief means that he controls the army. Congress' power to declare war means that they decide when the army can be used on another sovereign state. All the commander in chief power means is that congress can't pass a resolution THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED THAT: The IV Corps be moved 5 miles North and attack Mosul. It doesn't mean that the president can do an end run around congress. Congress still must, in my view, declare war in order for the president to send troops into combat. As the Washington Post tells us on March 12th 2003, it can be reasonably argued that the clause granting congress the power to declare war was meant as a check on an unbridled executive power to throw american lives and drain the american treasury on a whim. In this sense, congress must give its explicit authorization IN THE FORM MANDATED BY THE CONSTITUTION for war to be constitutional. This manner is a declaration of war. Does this mean I think the Korean war and Vietnam were unconstitutional? Yes. Furthermore, the congressional resolution itself is unconstitutional, because it delegates congressional power (declaring war) to the presidency without any guidelines or standards for the president to meet. In doing this, it violates the seperation of powers, and specifically Panama Refining Co. v. Ryan and Schecter Poultry Co. v. US. Congress cannot delegate the powers vested in it to the presidency, though presidents can "Fill in the details" of congressional acts. However, the court has specifically said that congress must provide some sort of guidelines and limitations to its delegation, and cannot give the sort of blanket approval that the resolution did.
 Norman then says in spite of this, art. 51 allows self-defense actions and thus the US can do it anyway. This is fallacious for two reasons. First, that this merely says that a defensive action is permissable under UN charters. It doesn't say that the nation can ignore its own legal standards when taking such an action. Third if pre-emption was ok under art 51, the US still has some obligation to prove that it is self-defense to attack Iraq, which it can't because a) Iraq has no weapons capable of reaching America (Al-Samoud missiles have a max range of no more than 100 miles) b) We have no connection from Iraq to al-qaeda except that a few al-qaeda folks are present in baghdad (and some are present in america too, that doesn't mean we support them) and that a pro al-qaeda group has established itself in a section of northern iraq that saddam doesnt even control. It seems highly doubtful that Iraq is supporting a group that has called its leader an infidel. c) Most defense experts agree that attacking Iraq will actually harm our national security interests, because it gives North Korea more oppurtunity to build up ITS arsenal (which currently has missiles that can reach america) but more importantly, because while the last thing Iraq, a secular state, would do is give up its weapons to radical muslim extremists (whose primary goals are to eliminate secular arab states) such as al-qaeda, the one situation where they might do such an action is if the US invades, because then they have nothing to lose by giving there weapons up.
 The Vietnam and N. Korea cases I have already dealt with, b/c they were in my view unconstitutional regardless of UN rules (incidentally, the UN didn't have a true court system, so no "interpretations" of UN statutes have been made). Israel is a false analogy because it most certainly has met the burden of proving self-defense. But it has been condemned repeatedly by the UN just the same.
 The War Powers Act, in essence was congress trying to regain some of the power it had lost by overbroad interpretations of executive power. Under a reasonable interpretation of the constitution it wouldn't have been necessary.
